results.title: Lines vertical
results.creator_credit: Evelyn Lambart, Norman McLaren and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: An experiment in pure design by film artists Norman McLaren and Evelyn Lambart. Lines ruled directly on the film move with precision and grace against a background of changing colours, in response to music composed by and played by Maurice Blackburn on the electronic piano. No commentary, music only.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Evelyn Lambart, Norman McLaren and ONF | NFB

results.title: Lines in relief: woodcut and block printing
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Shows how a fine woodcut is made, explaining the selection of tools and materials, the transfer of the design, and the techniques used in cutting the block. Illustrates the step by step process of printing a woodcut in several colors. Includes a brief review of the history of woodcuts and block printing from the Middle Ages to the present.
results.title_for_label: Lines in relief: woodcut and block printing
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films

results.title: Lines and volumes
results.creator_credit: Krzysztof Talczewski, Jean-Jacques Besnard, Jean-Paul Thomas, La Cinquieme, T O P, Vision 7 and XXle Siecle
results.brief_description: A series of reflective vignettes on a range of art movements from Impressionism to 20th century urban architecture with a focus on a personal exploration of key artists in each period. The impact of cinema and photography on art is discussed at the opening of the program in the context of Impressionism and its quality of perception overriding senses of description followed by a brief analysis of the life and work of Auguste Renoir and Claude Monet. The program then moves to Montmatre in the early 1900s where Cubism began to be recognised and Picasso emerged as a key artist and then on to Surrealism and the artistic debates of the 1920s where Breton, Max Ernst, Giorgio De Chirico, Francis Picabia, Rene Magritte, Jean Cocteau, Manray and the celebrated Dadaist, Salvador Dali are explored. The emergence of the New Realists proclaiming the end of all art and all styles is then discussed with particular attention to the life and work of Yves Plant, Cezarre and Marc Chagall. This is followed by a focus on Urban landscapes and architecture from the Bauhaus School and detailed analysis of the work of Raymond Loewy to a study of urban postwar reconstruction and Skyrise buildings. Particular attention is directed here to the architecture of Frank Lloyd Wright and his successor Ieoh Ming Pei, dedicated to light and transparency in architecture most evident in his Louvre Museum entry redevelopment. The documentary closes with a symbolic meeting of the one of the oldest and one of the newest art forms, painting and cinema, in the form of Henri Georges Clouzot’s short film of Picasso at work on a backlit screen, “The Picasso Mystery”.

results.title: Lines - horizontal (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Evelyn Lambart, Norman McLaren and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: An experiment in pure design by film artists Norman McLaren and Evelyn Lambart. Lines, ruled directly on film, move with precision and grace against a background of changing colours in response to music specially composed for the film. Accompanied by American folk musician Pete Seeger on wind and string instruments. (Awards: Venice; Edinburgh; London)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Evelyn Lambart, Norman McLaren and ONF | NFB

results.title: Line to Tschierva hut
results.creator_credit: Alberto Cavalcanti, GPO Film Unit and Pro Telephon Zurich
results.brief_description: Documents the effort by Swiss and British engineers to lay a telephone line to an alpine hut in Switzerland’s Roseg Valley. The films shows some of the hazards encountered and the difficulties overcome in establishing telephone communication through the mountainous, but beautiful, countryside. Cinematography, John Taylor. Music, Maurice Jaubert.

results.title: Line of balance
results.creator_credit: Walter Storey, Peter Bradford and World Wide Pictures
results.brief_description: Line of balance is a programming technique developed by production engineers to plan and control manufacturing processes in factories. Illustrates adaption for use on building sites. Uses animation to explain the basic principles of the techniques, and shows use of the management disciplines of mass production.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Walter Storey, Peter Bradford and World Wide Pictures

results.title: Line and Nantha (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Line and Nantha are a couple trying to overcome the restrictive sex-role conditioning they were taught as they were growing up. Nantha talks about his family life in Malaysia and Line describes the everyday sexism of her family in Quebec. They are trying to become a couple and to create a relationship that is egalitarian.

results.title: Limon's legacy
results.creator_credit: George A. Dolney, Marvin A Lipman and United States Information Agency
results.brief_description: Jose Limon who died in 1962 was a major dancer and choreographer from the second generation of modern American dancers, and his works reflected both the tragedy and grandeur of the human spirit. He saw dance as a “vision of ineffable power”. Segments of Limon’s choreography are presented.

results.title: Limbering up
results.creator_credit: Frank Gardner and Central Office of Information
results.brief_description: Some of Britain’s outstanding young athletes seen at practice and in action. Sprinters David Jones and Jennie Smart, diver Brian Phelps and swimmer Anita Lonsborough, are among those who show their paces; analyses points of style and movement.
